resources.string: Of 200 million sperm, one reaches the egg in a fallopian tube and fertilizes it. The outermost layer of the egg hardens now so that no other sperm can penetrate.

Of 200 million sperm, one reaches the egg in a fallopian tube and fertilizes it. This determines the genetic code of the embryo. Eye color, sex, character: a unique human being emerges. Cell division begins and the first pregnancy hormones are formed.

The egg has divided several times and has grown into a small ball, which already differentiates into baby and placenta. This ball now migrates through the fallopian tubes to the uterus and implants into the mucosa. Some women notice this process as mild implantation bleeding. Through further cell divisions, the cells specialize and begin forming organs, nervous system and brain. The cardiovascular system, spine, connective and muscle tissue, and reproductive organs also begin to develop. An embryo is formed.
At the end of this week you may discover that you are pregnant. Menstruation does not occur and the embryo has formed enough hormones that they are detectable with a pregnancy test.

The embryo is already about as big as a grain of rice. This week, the head, brain, blood cells and veins are forming. In the ultrasonic your baby looks like a small bright spot in a dark capsule, the amniotic sac . At the end of the 5th Week its tiny heart starts beating. The embryo is now connected to the placenta with a rudimentary umbilical cord. By now, pregnant women should stop (and not only reduce) their alcohol and cigarette consumption completely, because the embryo is very sensitive. Fortunately, most women develop a natural aversion to such toxins. Additionally it is now possible that first symptoms occur. The hormonal changes can cause nausea, severe olfactory sensibility, irritability , fatigue, constipation or bloating.

The embryo is now 6 mm long and appears stretched. It looks like a small bean. Small buds, the future arms and legs, are emerging from the embryo\'s body. This week the face is developing. Furthermore, vital organs such as liver, stomach and intestines are beginning to grow. The spinal cord is present and one can already see the eye sockets and mouth. The fetus moves gently, swaying in the amniotic fluid. Some women feel in early pregnancy an ache in their stomach similar to the onset of menstruation. This is due to stretching of the ligaments and the uterus and is no reason to worry.

The embryo is now growing very fast, about one millimeter larger every day. The size of the embryo is indicated in the crown-rump length (CRL), the distance measured from the head to the buttocks. The digestive tract, heart, kidneys, brain and lungs are in place and continue to develop now. This time is an important stage of development. By the 10th week of pregnancy, all organ systems are ready and only need to mature.

The embryo now has a size of 9 to 16 mm (CRL). The heart of the unborn child is now beating 140 to 150 times a minute. The spine is now mobile, because vertebral bodies have formed around the spinal cord. The nerve cells of the embryo are now in a particularly sensitive phase and are therefore very vulnerable to toxins. If harmful substances such as drugs, alcohol or certain medicines are consumed now, they can lead to serious damage later.

The size of the embryo is now 17 to 24 mm (CRL). The arms, hands, legs and feet are now clearly visible. In boys, the testicles develop now. A distinction between the sexes by ultrasound is not yet possible. However if you have an ultrasound now you can clearly see your baby\'s movements. It will take some time until you can feel them, too. An ultrasound examination between the 9th and the 12th Gestation determines whether the heart beats and the embryo moves properly. The uterus has now significantly gained size and can press on the bladder.

The size of the embryo is now 25 to 33 mm (CRL) and weighs less than 4g. On the ultrasound, strong movements can be seen. The face of the unborn can be seen more clearly now. The eyelids are still closed. The vital organs - liver, kidneys, intestines, brain and lungs - are fully developed and functional. The head is half as big as the rest of the body. The forehead is bulging and appears disproportionately large. The riskiest time of the pregnancy is now coming to an end. The risk of miscarriage is now rapidly reduced. The fluctuating hormone levels are now especially noticeable in the mood of the pregnant woman. Between absolute elation and tearful desperation, anything is possible. In the second trimester of pregnancy, these fluctuations settle down somewhat.

The face of the unborn is now completely formed, although the eyelids remain closed. The fetus now measures about 3 cm and weighs about 15g. The skin is covered by soft down. The pregnancy is almost not visible from the outside yet. The breasts have grown somewhat and your pants may feel tight. The mother\'s heart must work harder due to the increased blood volume. You may feel tired and a bit short of breath. Give yourself an extra break now and then. Exercise is good for you, because circulation helps supply the placenta with more oxygen. However, avoid strenuous athletic performance.

The fetus is now about 5 cm long and weighs 16 g. The small heart beats 120 to 160 times a minute. The muscles are now developed enough that elbows and wrists can be flexed. The hands can move. Spleen, liver and bone marrow develop an independent blood formation system. By the end of the 12th week, most women have passed the time of morning sickness. If you still suffer from severe sickness and lose weight, talk to your doctor about it. The mother\'s pelvis, tendons and joints are becoming softer and more pliable due to pregnancy hormones. This also applies to the intervertebral discs.

The weight of the fetus is about 18 g, about 6 cm in size (CRL), and the head diameter is 21 mm. The organs of the fetus have finished their development now and just need to grow. The first bones are starting to form from cartilage tissue. The baby is already able to move its lips, frown and yawn. From now on, the size of the fetus is determined by measuring the head. The placenta is now reaching its full function. It supplies the baby with nutrients and oxygen. At the same time it acts as a barrier against some harmful substances.

The diameter of the fetal head is now 25 mm and the weight is around 25 g. If you are really lucky, a doctor might be able to determine your baby\'s sex, as the genitals are developing clearly. All organ systems are functional now. For example, the baby practices breathing movements, though its oxygen is provided by the placenta. Touch, taste, and sense of balance are well developed. In addition, the sucking reflex and the grasping reflex are already working.

The head diameter of the fetus is now 28 to 37 mm, the weight is around 80 g and will grow rapidly. From now on, your baby can hear what is going on. For bone development, your baby needs sufficient calcium now. The heart is almost fully developed. The liver and the pancreas begin to function. The risk of urinary tract infection is very high now. Be sure to drink enough water and see your doctor at the first sign of infection.

The head diameter of the child is now 32 to 40 mm, it weighs approximately 90 g and is 9.4 cm long. The rapid development of the organs is now largely complete. Now it\'s mainly about the small body gaining size and weight. The fetus begins to stretch now. Hair, eyelashes and eyebrows grow. If you are older than 35 years or have an increased risk of having a child with a chromosomal disorder, your doctor will speak with you about an amniocentesis. This can determine the chromosomes and possible disorders of the unborn.

The baby now has a head diameter of 35 to 44 mm and weighs approximately 100 g. Perhaps you can now feel the first gentle fetal movements. The baby\'s hands and sense of touch are now developed enough that it can grab the umbilical cord. The unborn now hears noises from outside, like the mother\'s heartbeat, her voice or music. The chance of recognizing the baby\'s sex via ultrasound is now particularly high.

The head diameter is now approximately 38 to 48 mm, the weight approximately 125 g. The unborn is approximately 12 cm long. Fetal movements are now clearly perceptible. You will clearly feel the difference between the rest phases and the active phases of the fetus. The movements are especially noticeable in the evening hours when you yourself come to rest. Calcium deficiency or the increased pressure of the uterus on the pelvic vessels can now cause cramps in the legs. Varicose veins can develop or worsen. The uterus has grown significantly in size. It has almost reached the height of the navel and pushes all organs somewhat upward. The belly grows visibly. The tension of the abdominal skin leads to the so-called linea nigra, a dark line from the navel to the pubic bone.

The baby\'s head has a diameter of 42 to 51 mm and weighs approximately 200 g. The uterus expands daily due to the increased fluid volume, which gives the baby more and more room to move. The fetus\'s eyes move back and forth, but the eyelids remain closed until the end of the 6th month of pregnancy. Now is the right time to think about where you want to give birth. Most childbirth preparation courses also begin around the 20th week. These courses competently prepare expectant mothers and fathers for the big event.

The head diameter is now about 46 to 55 mm, weight about 300 g. The fetus does not develop quite as rapidly anymore. Now small fat deposits are created that are necessary after birth for heat regulation. The baby swallows a small amount of amniotic fluid every day and excretes it through the urinary tract again. This way, kidneys and swallowing can be trained. The mother can now perceive quite strong fetal movements.

The fetus will gain weight very quickly now. The vestibular organ is fully developed, the baby is now able to perceive itself. The skin of the fetus is covered with fine downy hair, called lanugo. It protects the skin and helps regulate body temperature. A whitish, waxy layer covers the body of the fetus - the vernix caseosa. It protects the skin from drying out and heat loss. Sometimes a painless hardening of the uterus can be felt. These are Braxton Hicks contractions, virtually a preliminary exercise of the body for birth. If the contractions are painful and occur frequently and regularly, you should contact your doctor. It may then be real, premature labor.

" The fetus\'s head now has a diameter of 52 to 62 mm, the child\'s weight is about 500 g. The baby develops a consistent sleep-wake cycle. It is increasingly developing an awareness of its environment. If you feel rhythmic twitches in your belly from time to time, this is not a reason for concern. The baby simply has hiccups. Train your pelvic floor with special exercises now. It must withstand the pressure of the baby. Stretch marks may now appear due to the strong stretching. They will not disappear completely, but will become significantly paler after birth."

The baby\'s head diameter now measures 58 to 69 mm, the weight is about 580 g. The quantity of amniotic fluid continues to increase and now contains dead cells, hair and skin cream. The baby now reacts with specific movements to sounds. The doctor will carefully monitor the hemoglobin level in the mother\'s blood from now on. This value gives information about the baby\'s oxygen supply.

The head diameter is now 61 to 72 mm, the weight is 700 g. The baby\'s sense of taste is already well developed. It responds to strong stimuli from the outside world with vigorous movements and accelerated pulse. The fat deposits of the fetus have developed to the point that the skin is taut and wrinkle-free.

The head now has a diameter of 64 to 75 mm, the baby weighs about 800 g. The possible movements of the fetus are becoming more and more restricted. The lungs continue to develop, but no oxygen is yet transferred from the lungs into the bloodstream - this happens through the umbilical cord, which also transports the used blood back to the placenta. There it is enriched with oxygen and returned to the child\'s bloodstream. The baby continues to diligently swallow amniotic fluid, training the urinary tract and digestive system. For many pregnant women, the nights are now uncomfortable. For one, the already large belly interferes with finding a comfortable sleeping position; on the other hand, the baby is particularly active at night. Thoughts about the birth and the future can sometimes disturb your sleep.

The head diameter is now 66 to 77 mm, the weight is about 900 g. The eyes are now open. If a light source is directed at the abdomen, the baby responds with increased movement and faster heartbeat. Babies born prematurely from the 27th week of pregnancy have a fairly good chance of survival. However, they need to be closely supervised by doctors for some time.

The baby\'s head diameter is now 70 to 80 mm, the approximate weight is 1000 g. The maturity of the lungs is now almost complete; the baby could now breathe independently if it were born now. Many pregnant women have had a low hemoglobin level in recent months. The body\'s iron stores are depleted. Additional iron may need to be supplemented to ensure adequate oxygen supply to the child. Now begins the most arduous period of pregnancy. The child needs more and more space. Typical symptoms for this part of pregnancy are heartburn, constipation, shortness of breath and increased urination. The spine is also heavily loaded and often reacts with pain.

The fetus\'s head diameter measures about 72 to 83 mm, weight about 1100 g. Many babies now move into the optimal birthing position with the head down. The fetal position and placental function are now carefully examined during screenings. The uterus now extends about 10 cm above the navel. Tissue fluid is now increasingly retained in the ankles. This edema is usually harmless and often disappears again the next morning. Elevate your legs as often as possible.

The baby\'s head diameter now measures 74 to 86 mm, the weight is about 1250 g. From the 30th week you will go more frequently for screenings. The doctor checks the heartbeat and the baby\'s position. The pregnancy is now usually very difficult and the fear of birth slowly gives way to anticipation of the day of delivery.

The baby\'s head diameter is now 76 to 88 mm, weight about 1400 g. The fetus is growing several centimeters during this period and puts on weight rapidly. Braxton Hicks contractions are now often felt. These are not painful, but uncomfortable. Some whitish liquid may leak from the breasts. This colostrum (first milk) is rich in nutrients and is already produced during pregnancy, especially in the first days after birth.

The head diameter is now 78 to 90 mm, weight about 1600 g. The baby now gains about 150 to 200 g per week. The baby\'s movements will now be slower and more leisurely, but very strong. Often they are observable from the outside. Almost all babies are now in the optimal position for birth, with the head down. Now it is time to take care of the baby\'s initial equipment. Get everything you still need by now at the latest.

" Your baby now weighs approximately 1800 g, has a head diameter of 80 to 93 mm, and a crown-to-heel length of about 41 to 43 cm. In the coming weeks, lightening contractions will help the baby\'s head settle firmly into the pelvis. Many babies turn into the cephalic position (head down) during this week to prepare for birth. However, it is still possible for the baby to turn multiple times before delivery. The baby continues to build up fat reserves, which will help regulate its body temperature after birth. Overall, the 32nd week of pregnancy marks the transition into the final phase of pregnancy, during which the baby continues to grow and prepare for life outside the womb."

The head diameter is now 82 to 95 mm, the baby weighs about 2000 g. Make sure during this time to consume enough calcium, because the baby has an extremely high demand. The baby may now be giving signals for birth. Pack your hospital bag and complete the preparations for your new little one. If large amounts of amniotic fluid leak out, you should immediately consult a doctor because the infection risk is increased enormously.

The head diameter is 84 to 97 mm, the baby weighs about 2250 g. The lightening contractions have ensured that the baby is positioned much deeper in the abdomen. This means enormous relief for many pregnant women. You can breathe better again, and heartburn and nausea subside. Give yourself adequate rest periods during this phase of pregnancy. The additional weight and the forward-arched belly are very taxing.

The head diameter is now 86 to 99 mm, the baby weighs about 2550 g. Now begins the waiting period. For many expectant mothers, it is a balancing act between feelings of fear and enormous anticipation. The passing of a mucous plug, the rupture of the amniotic sac and the onset of labor contractions announce an approaching delivery date. Talk to your doctor or midwife about any of these events.

The head diameter is now 87 to 101 mm, weight about 2750 g. The baby\'s fingernails and toenails are now completely formed, and the hair can now have a considerable length of up to 5 cm. The mother\'s body prepares for breastfeeding. Through the placenta, 80 liters of blood flow every day now.

The baby\'s head diameter is 89 to 102 mm, weight about 2950 g. The baby is now fully ready for birth in every respect. The cranial sutures at the baby\'s head will only completely ossify during the first year of life. This has the advantage that they can be pushed together somewhat in the birth canal, making the birth easier.

The head diameter is 90 to 103 mm in size now, the baby weighs about 3100 g. For the baby, it is now really tight in the womb. There is not much space left for movements. When the baby is awake, its eyes are constantly open.

Your baby now weighs about 3250 g and measures about 50 cm (crown-to-heel length). The last days of pregnancy have begun. The wait is often unbearable. Many women now feel the so-called "nesting instinct". You have virtually inexhaustible energy and start a major cleaning and organizing spree. Nevertheless, it is important that you allow yourself enough rest breaks now. You will need a lot of strength for the birth.

10 of 100 pregnancies beyond the due date. The woman physician / gynecologist at short intervals will test whether the placenta provides the baby still enough oxygen and nutrients. Most calculation errors are the reason for exceeding the birth date. Under certain circumstances, the birth is now also introduced artificially in order to prevent transmission. The great day of birth will come in this time and for you to start a new life.

10 out of 100 pregnancies go beyond the due date. The gynecologist will test at short intervals whether the placenta still provides the baby with enough oxygen and nutrients. Most often, calculation errors are the reason for exceeding the birth date. Under certain circumstances, the birth may now be artificially induced to prevent post-term pregnancy. The great day of birth will come during this time and a new phase of life will begin for you.

10 out of 100 pregnancies go beyond the due date. The gynecologist will test at short intervals whether the placenta still provides the baby with enough oxygen and nutrients. Most often, calculation errors are the reason for exceeding the birth date. Under certain circumstances, the birth may now be artificially induced to prevent post-term pregnancy. The great day of birth will come during this time and a new phase of life will begin for you.
